lines.text: Striker was the squadron leader. He brought us in real low. But he couldn't handle it.
Buddy couldn't handle it? Was Buddy one of your crew?
Right. Buddy was the bombardier. But it was Striker who couldn't handle it, and he went to pieces.
*Andy* went to pieces?
No. Andy was the navigator. He was all right. Buddy went to pieces. It was awful how he came unglued.
*Howie* came unglued?
Oh, no. Howie was a rock, the best tailgunner in the outfit. Buddy came unglued.
And he bailed out?
No. Andy hung tough. Buddy bailed out. How he survived, it was a miracle.
Then Howie survived?
No, 'fraid not. We lost Howie the next day.
Dr. Stone, would you give the court your impression of Mr. Striker?
I'm sorry, I don't do impressions... my training is in psychiatry.
Dad never slaps me around at home, must be his coffee.
No, I've been serving him decafe. Maybe he's just an asshole.
Gentlemen, I'd like you to meet your captain, Captain Oveur.
Gentlemen, welcome aboard.
Captain, your navigator, Mr. Unger, and your first officer, Mr. Dunn.
Unger.
Oveur.
Oveur.
Dunn. Gentlemen, let's get to work.
Unger, didn't you serve under Oveur in the Air Force?
Not directly. Technically, Dunn was under Oveur and I was under Dunn.
Yep.
So, Dunn, you were under Oveur and over Unger.
Yep.
That's right. Dunn was over Unger and I was over Dunn.
So, you see, both Dunn and I were under Oveur, even though I was under Dunn.
Dunn was over Unger, and I was over Dunn.
Jacobs, I want to know absolutely everything that's happened up till now.

Well, let's see. First the earth cooled. And then the dinosaurs came, but they got too big and fat, so they all died and they turned into oil. And then the Arabs came and they bought Mercedes Benzes. And Prince Charles started wearing all of Lady Di's clothes. I couldn't believe it.
Jacobs, what have you got on Elaine Dickinson?
Well, I'm two inches taller, a better dancer, and much more fun to be with.
Do you swear on the Constitution of the United States to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, so help you God?
Ain't no thing.
[he slaps the clerk's book and the clerk uses his book to slap the witnesses hand as if "giving fives" to each other]

[approaches the witness as he sits down in the witness stand]
Would you describe, in your own words, what happened that night?
Check it, bleed. Bro... was ON! Didn't trip. But the folks was freakin', Man. Hey, and the pilots were laid to the bone, Homes.
[the stenographer wears sunglasses and sways back and forth as he types]
So Blood hammered out and jammed jet ship. Tightened that bad sucker inside the runway like a mother. Shit.
Over Macho Grande?
No. I don't think I'll ever get over Macho Grande.
[the Wilson family arrives at the checkpoint]
Can I help you folks?
Oh, yes, thank you.
Aw, is that your dog, son?
[looking at Scraps, Jimmy's dog]
Yes, his name is Scraps, and he's going to the moon with us.
Oh no. No dogs are allowed in the shuttle son. I'm affraid Scraps will have to be shot.
[pulls out a gun, shoots the dog and the dog falls to the floor]

[shouts, bending towards his dog]
Scraps! He shot him! He shot Scraps! He shot him!
Just joking. Blanks, see? Scraps is fine.
[Dog stands up]
[laughing]
Get me Steve McCroskey!
Are you kidding? Ever since Reagan fired the air traffic controllers, he's been completely senile!
Yeah, but what about McCroskey?
About the same as Reagan.
Just a few more hours and change 'til liftoff.
I'm very excited, Simon.
Guess this is a first for you, eh kid?
No, I've been excited before.

[speaking into handset]
Hello, this is the Mayflower. Come in. Anyone?
Okay okay. Now we're making some headway.
[responds into handset]
Yeah yeah, we read you Mayflower. Identify yourself.
Well, this is Elaine Dickinson. I'm 5-foot-8, 123 pounds. I have, uh, brown hair, blue eyes. I enjoy surfing, backgammon and men who aren't afraid to cry.

[in the cockpit]
I guess it's in God's hands now.

[in cabin area]
I'm Father O'Flanagan, and I am a man of God. Therefore you must trust me when I tell you that we're all likely going to die.

[Mary is walking down the aisle among passengers]
When we're ready we would like to ask you to remove your eyeglasses and shoes and place your head between the knees.
[She glances towards an attractive lady]
Between your own knees, Father.
[Father O'Flannagan pulls his head up from the attractive lady's lap]
Irony can be pretty ironic sometimes.
We'd better get to the tower, Lieutenant.
We have no tower, sir.
No tower?
Just a bridge, sir.
Why the *hell* aren't I notified about these things?
And how about the time we hopped in the family car and drove all the way to Woodstock?

Oh, that was a time. You got hold of that bad acid and didn't come down for two weeks, you kept telling everyone that you were Jesus Christ and then you jumped off a roof 'cause you thought you could fly!
What a bummer.
No shit.
Where is the passenger processing lounge for the lunar shuttle?
Concourse lounge C, fourth level.
Thank you.
Next?
How long is my parking permit good for?
Two hours.
Thank you.
Yes, next?
What's the fastest animal on Earth?
The cheetah. Next?
Should I fake my orgasms?
Yes.
Thank you.
Next?
Where am I going to get a piece of metal?... Out here in space?... At this hour?

[after hearing Striker on the radio]
A man - now that's more like it.
[to the radio]
Come in Mayflower 1, give me your name and position.
My name's Striker and I'm sitting down and facing front. Why would you want to know that?

courage, dedication, daring, pride, pluck, spirit, grit, mettle, and G-U-T-S, *guts*. Why, Ted Striker's got more guts in his little finger than most of us have in our large intestine, including the colon!
Can I ask you a question?
What is it?
It's an interrogative statement, used to test knowledge. But that's not important now, mister. Is my dog Scraps, is gonna make it through okay? I'm scared mister, somebody has to do something.
Scraps, is going to be fine son. You'll both, be just fine.
[Striker, puts Jimmy's face in the icing of the cake]
Striker, listen to me. I don't want you, to do this they forced me to cut corners...
Get outta my way!
Help me, Striker for Christ -
[Striker, slugs Simon in the face]

Oh, cut the bleeding heart crap, will ya? We've all got our switches, lights, and knobs to deal with, Striker. I mean, down here there are literally hundreds and thousands of blinking, beeping, and flashing lights, blinking and beeping and flashing - they're *flashing* and they're *beeping*. I can't stand it anymore! They're *blinking* and *beeping* and *flashing*! Why doesn't somebody pull the plug!
Striker? Striker, Striker,
[turns away from his control screen]
*Strike Her*!
[a man behind McCroskey punches a woman]
Voice interface.
There's an overheat in the core. Please analyze problem.
There is no apparent overheat.
Yes, there is, ROC. We read a core overheat. Repeat analysis.
Analysis confirmed. All systems compute positive.
Well, not from where I'm sitting, they don't!
Look, Elaine. Cut the "not from where I'm sitting" shit. It must be a human error.
[Elaine turns to the captain]
Captain, I think we have a computer foul-up!
I see.
Well, what do you recommend, Captain?
Maybe you'd better run it through the computer.
But sir, I already have!
Good!

[speaking to the entire control room]
Now listen to me and listen good. If you got any ideas, any ideas at all, now is the time. I want to hear them and I want to hear them now!
How about a game show like Hollywood Squares but with kids? Gary Coleman could host.
Uh, Captain, I'm picking up an overheat in the computer core.
How serious is it, Mr. Dunn?
Uh, I can't tell sir.
Well you can tell me - I'm the Captain.

Listen good. That thing is bound to come apart on you at that speed, and that's no good! It's got to be in one piece when you land on the moon! You know damn well that that warp drive has never been tested!
[stabs his cigarette into the left hand of the controller sitting next to him]
You're putting yourself and everybody else on that ship in jeopardy!
[cuts to the cabin of the shuttle, where Art Fleming is suddenly doing a match of Jeopardy! with the passengers as the contestants]
All right, Contestant #38.
Art, I'll take Air Shuttle Disasters for $40.
The answer is...
[the display with $40 on it rotates to reveal the answer]
... the Mayflower!
We're going to have to blow up the computer!
Blow ROC?
[a smiling face appears on the computer]
Those lights are blinking out of sequence.
Make them blink in sequence.
Ted, I have the strangest feeling we've been through this exact same thing before.
I'm gonna go get Ted, just don't fall apart on me now!
We're not in the past anymore, Elaine. This... is the FUTURE.
[the controllers thinking about the people in the hijacked airplane]
They're screwed!
They're dead!
Did I leave the iron on?
Don't worry about the Viatex account, we have a buy or sell option; we can't get hurt in either case.
Just keep on top of their legal people, Bob.
Will do.
[Two men kiss]
And Bob, feed the cats.
Will do.
I'm Father O'Flanagan, and I am a man of God. Therefore you must trust me when I tell you that we're all likely going to die.

[All of the passengers start panicking and start punching each other. A hockey referee is seen trying to separate the attacking members of his hockey team, and other passengers are repeatedly slugging the same people over and over]
"Man Has Sex Change - Marries Self."]
Lunar Shuttle heads for the Sun, and Certain Disaster.
American Lunar Mission Locked in Death Struggle.
[on the monitor behind him is a clip of Godzilla eating a Lunar Shuttle]

[with a gun being held to his head]
A four-alarm fire in Downtown Moscow clears way for a glorious new tractor factory, And, on the lighter side of the news, Hundreds of Capitalists are Soon to Perish in Shuttle Disaster.
[as we cut to the next clip, the sound of a gunshot is heard]

[on a talk show]
If this canned beet was run by vegetarian women rather than flesh-eating men, this whole space disaster would never have happened. You know right now, we're working to raise the consciousness of the vegetarian minorities with diet sensitivity training, so that people will be able to deal with the foul...

[Ted climbs over the wall guarding the mental hospital, removes his gown revealing regular clothes and throws the gown out of harm's way. The gown comes back and covers Ted's head. Ted drops the gown beside him and starts to run while trying to avoid being spotted by a searchlight. Ted pauses when he encounters a lounge singer in a spotlight. The singer wears a tuxedo with his bow tie untied and he holds a microphone. It's Jack Jones]

[sings]
... floats back to you... Ooo, The Love Boat... soon will be making another run. The Love Boat...
[Ted continues to run]
Stryker, you get that ship down... and down safe...
[a giant money safe falls behind Murdock]
... there just might be a few of us who will forget Macho Grande.
Ok Murdock, I think I got something that just might work.
what?
A bobby pin.
Bobby pin. What the hell's, a man doing with a bobby pin. Lights on
[Turns lights on]
All right Striker, if a bobby pin is what you got, you will have to do. Just shove it in there, you'll have to short that thing out.
[Shoves the bobby pin, into the broken lever compartment, and sparks]

[he hears lots of static on his two-way radio]
Striker, you're fading out! Come in. Over.
[more static]
Damn! We lost him!
Could be those sun spots.
Could be your dishwashing detergent.
Would somebody please tell me what in Sam Hill a woman is doing up there in charge of that ship?
Well maybe she's got her ship together.
Mr. Dunn, what's your temperature reading?

[takes thermometer out of his mouth and reads it]
Uh, 98.6 sir.
That sounds normal.
My God! The sun.
What is it, Simon?
A large, fiery ball at the center of our solar system, but that's not important now. We're heading right for it.
Excuse me, ma'am. There's some, pretty badly banged up, people back there. I'm gonna need some fresh sheets, guaze, Q-Tips, and all the vasoline you have on board.
Ted, Please.
Right now!
Are you, the nurse?
Yes, take this. The washroom's, just right down there, on the right.

[TV Version]
There's nothing, to worry about.
Could you, hand me your cup please? Thank you. Be careful, it's very hot, okay.
Thank you, and stewardess, would you please tell my wife, that these flights are completely safe? I hope, she hears it from you.
There's nothing, to worry about.
[Unger's hand sticking out, of the door]
[Screams, and drops the last pitcher of coffee on the female passenger]
[Screams, after Testa dropped the coffee on her]

[as he and the commissioner get out of their car and enter the terminal building]
Commissioner, now we both know that shuttle needs another month of pre-launch testing.
Forget it.
Commissioner.
I said forget about it. The Mayflower is the first Lunar Shuttle to fly from a commercial terminal, and the boys on the board want that flight to go on schedule.
Well the boys on the board know about safety...
Bud, get wise to the political reality. The boys on the board are under a heavy pressure from the boys downtown.

[the elevator arrives, and the doors open. Several people exit, all of them covering their ears because the elevator music is very, *very* loud. Everyone files into the elevator and puts their hands over their ears to protect them from the music, except for Bud and the Commissioner. The doors close, silencing the music]
[At the fourth floor, everyone files out, and the loud elevator music is playing a rendition of "Raindrops Keep Falling On My Head."]

[the first part of what he says is drowned out by the loud music]
The boys on the board are under pressure from the boys downtown.
And I'll be the one to crucify if that shuttle screws up.
So the company's actually doing very well. We're just raising the figures of the last quarter, they show a 40% increase over the past year.

[looking at the patient's chart]
Visiting hours are over.
Doctor, do you think my brother will be able to come home to the farm soon?
It's hard to say, it's a difficult case. He still thinks he's an accountant.
Okay.
[Nurses, meanwhile, are trying to restrain the patient who thinks he's an accountant]
You must believe me! Invest in money markets!
Get me radio contact with that ship, pronto!
Yes, sir!

[walks over carrying some papers. He is carrying them with an oven mitt]
Here's all the available information on the sun, sir. That thing is *hot*.
[McCroskey touches the hot papers and burns his hand]
Get me Bud Kruger immediately and some ice!
Yes, sir.
Jacobs.
[Jacobs hops over]
I want to know absolutely everything that's happened up 'til now.

First, the Earth cooled. And then the dinosaurs came, but they got too big and fat, so they all died and they turned into oil. And then the Arabs came and they bought Mercedes-Benzes. And Prince Charles started wearing all of Lady Di's clothes. I couldn't believe it.
[Jacobs turns and starts to walk away, continuing to speak, trailing off as he gets further from the camera]
He took her best summer dress out of the closet and he put it on and went to town...

[walks over to a wall and stands next to a portrait that depicts him standing next to a portrait that depicts him]
Things sure haven't changed.
Anti-gravity check.
All right.
[presses a button, which causes the crewman in the spacesuit who is listening and moving to the beat of "Car Wash" on his headphones to float in the air]
Checks out in positive mode, sir.
Check.
[the spacesuit man is still floating upside down]
Checks out in negative mode, sir.
Check.
Neutral balance seems all right, sir.
Good, that shall do it.
Anti-gravity off, sir.
[Turns off the anti-gravity, causing the spacesuit crewman to fall to the floor]
Hope this weather doesn't give us a problem.
[He sticks his hand out the window to feel the temperature]
Mr. Dunn, what's your temperature reading?

[takes thermometer out of his mouth and reads the mercury level]
Uh, 98.6 sir.
That sounds normal.
I don't know if this is a good time to ask, but would it be possible for me to get my briefcase back?
Well, my goodness, Scraps is a boy dog, isn't he?
Yeah.
Jimmy, do you like it when Scraps holds onto your leg and rubs up and down?
Jimmy, do you ever wonder why dogs sniff each other?
Can I ask you a question?
What is it?
It's an interrogative statement, used to test knowledge. But that's not important right now...
Passenger's name is Joe Saluki. He was supposed to fly to Des Moines for an operation, something to do with sexual impotence...
The Des Moines Institute?
You know it?
We're familiar with it.
Which passenger is Joe Solucci?
16C. Why?
He's carrying a bomb.
A bo - ?
No, not a bo-. A bomb. Now, discreetly as possible, I want you to move the passengers, into the lounge.
We don't, have a lounge.
That's not important right now but, you got to do is get those people away from that bomb.
Well, what should I say?
Anything. Just don't let Solucci think that we're onto him.
I'll do my best.

[Over Intercom]
Attention ladies and gentlemen, please. Would everybody move to the lounge who is not carrying a bomb.
[Everyone on the plane stands up and screams]
